;;诺贝尔经济学奖获得者、美国经济学家克劳迪娅·戈尔丁接受媒体采访2023 年 10 月 9 日在马萨诸塞州剑桥哈佛大学举行。（摄影：Lauren Owens Lambert / 法新社）;
;

;诺贝尔经济学奖授予克劳迪娅·戈尔丁 (Claudia Goldin)，以表彰她在工作场所男性和女性之间的;差距;。

;

;瑞典皇家科学院周一宣布了该奖项。 77岁的戈尔丁是过去93位诺贝尔经济学奖得主中的第三位女性。她是哈佛大学教授。

;

;戈尔丁的研究表明，即使在经济学领域，女性的收入也比男性低 13% 左右。薪酬差距阻碍了一些女性继续接受教育。

;
;;;哈佛大学教授经济历史学家克劳迪娅·戈尔丁 (Claudia Goldin) 抵达剑桥举行的新闻发布会，她因研究男女工资不平等的工作而获得 2023 年诺贝尔经济学奖，美国马萨诸塞州，2023 年 10 月 9 日。（路透社/Reba Saldanha）;
;

;诺贝尔委员会称赞戈尔丁发现了缺失的数据，以更好地解释薪酬和工作投入或参与之间的持续差异，男性和女性。

;

;该组织称戈尔丁为“一位;侦探;”，他发现了新的数据源和“利用它们来衡量这些未知数的创造性方法。”

;

;戈尔丁研究了 200 多年来与女性参与工作场所相关的信息，发现她们的工资一开始很低，而且从未赶上男性。

;

;她研究了那些工作未被统计的女性，例如那些与丈夫一起在农场工作或在家制作衣服。戈尔丁表示，当时存在的薪酬差距至今仍然存在，即使女性获得的教育水平高于男性。

;

;她说，在 20 世纪 90 年代，美国女性的劳动参与率领先于世界。但此后比率有所下降。

;

;“我认为美国发生了一些事情，”戈尔丁说。 “我们必须……提出如何将家庭、家庭……与市场和就业结合起来的问题。”戈尔丁指出，尽管女性在教育方面取得了进步，但她们仍然经常感到留在家里的压力照顾孩子或选择让孩子有机会参与的工作。

;
;;;2023年10月9日，诺贝尔经济学奖获得者美国经济学家克劳迪娅·戈尔丁在马萨诸塞州剑桥哈佛大学接受媒体采访。（劳伦·欧文斯·兰伯特摄） / 法新社）;
;

;“她们的大学毕业率比男性高得多。她们在高中的表现比男性好。那么为什么会出现这些差异呢？”戈尔丁问道。

;

;诺贝尔委员会的兰迪·哈尔马森 (Randi Hjalmarsson) 表示，戈尔丁的工作并未提供该问题的具体解决方案。然而，她说戈尔丁确实确定了“差距的根源，以及它如何随着时间的推移而变化……”

;

;Hjalmarsson 补充道，“通过最终理解问题并用正确的名称来称呼它，我们将能够铺平更好的前进道路。”

;

;戈尔丁建议男性需要更好地分担育儿和工作责任。她说，女性常常会因工作时间延长或周末而错过职业发展，因为她们感​​到照顾孩子的压力。

;

;她还建议美国政府在课后教育上投入更多资金程式。 “我们中很少有人会在下午 3 点完成工作，”她说。戈尔丁指出，加拿大、法国和日本的女性目前的劳动参与率高于美国

;

;戈尔丁表示，有些工作仍然需要;夫妇;来完成。她指出，“夫妻平等也会带来更多的性别平等。”戈尔丁还指出，女孩们关注她们的母亲如何参与工作，并且“每一代人都从;前几代人;的成功和失败中学习。”

;

;该奖项附带奖金约为 100 万美元，将于今年晚些时候在瑞典举行的颁奖典礼上颁发。

;

;我是 Dan Friedell。

;

;

; Tue, 10 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 London’s Pointe Black Ballet School Aims to Break Racial Barriershttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/london-s-pointe-black-ballet-school-aims-to-break-racial-barriers/7296762.html

;;7 月 22 日，英国伦敦南部，普安特布莱克芭蕾舞学校的露丝·埃塞尔 (Ruth Essel) 教授收尾姿势，2023 年。埃塞尔将其视为黑人舞者的安全空间，也是创建工作室、舞者和教师网络的一种方式。 （路透社/Alishia Abounde）;
;

;正是对她的非洲;辫子;头发的批评促使露丝·埃塞尔为黑人舞者创造了她所谓的安全空间。

;

;伦敦Pointe Black芭蕾舞学校的创始人表示，当她还是个孩子的时候，老师和其他人几乎都因为她不遵循传统的;芭蕾舞;方式而惩罚她。

; < p>;“我永远不会忘记我第一次在西区;舞台;上跳舞，”埃塞尔说。那时，10岁的女孩在练习舞蹈时把头发编成辫子。她的母亲花了最后 120 美元去做头发。

;

;当她的老师在一群几乎全是白人的舞者中指着她时，她的快乐消失了。老师让她把辫子拔掉，因为它看起来“一团糟”。

;

;这只是埃塞尔多次因为与众不同而感到难过的其中一次。 “这些都是我 16 岁之前发生的事情，我当时并不清楚，”她说。

;
;;;Maya，10 岁，Kioni，10 岁，Keturah，8 岁，和 Dior， 10、2023 年 1 月 21 日，在英国伦敦南部，下课时拥抱 30 岁的 Pointe Black 芭蕾舞学校创始人 Ruth Essel。（REUTERS/Alishia Abounde）;
;

;这些困难2020 年，26 岁的 Essel 带领 Essel 创立了 Pointe Black。

;

;“我希望那里有一个黑人环境。我希望有人看起来像我。我希望有一位像我一样的老师。”她说。

;

;她说，当她终于可以穿黑色的衣服和鞋子而不是传统的粉红色芭蕾舞演员时，感觉就像被赋予了力量， “因为它更接近我的颜色。”

;

;芭蕾舞已经扩展到世界各地，来自亚洲、南美洲和古巴的著名芭蕾舞演员也加入其中。但许多人仍然认为芭蕾舞演员肤色较浅。古典芭蕾舞团也试图在《天鹅湖》等古典作品中为舞者打造类似的造型。这使得有色人种舞者的处境变得更加困难。

;

;英国四大芭蕾舞团的舞者中约有 2.2% 是黑人血统。英国舞蹈研究协会的 Sandie Bourn 在 2017 年表示，这一比例与该国 3% 的黑人人口比例一致。

;

;一位发言人指出，保持;多样性;对每个人都很重要在皇家舞蹈学院，说“舞蹈适合每个人。”

;
;;;10 岁的 Dior、10 岁的 Maya、10 岁的 Kioni 和 8 岁的 Kalani 与 30 岁的 Pointe 创始人 Ruth Essel 一起欢笑黑色芭蕾舞学校，英国伦敦，2023 年 8 月 4 日，课程结束时。（路透社/Alishia Abounde）;
;

;但埃塞尔希望通过引入新想法来加速变革。她说她的节目使用非洲舞蹈和音乐。舞者有着不同的发型，包括麻花、卷发和爆炸式发型。她补充道，“……这实际上只是为了庆祝这个人，无论他们来自哪里。”

;

;Maya Beale-Springe 是 Pointe Black 和另一所芭蕾舞学校的 10 岁学生。她喜欢探索不同种类或类型的芭蕾舞。

;

;“我可以体验不同类型的芭蕾舞、不同的音乐，”她在为即将到来的演出进行完美练习后说道。

;

;埃塞尔教授她学校的所有课程。她说，“我学校的一切都是我年轻时想要的。”

;

;我是吉尔·罗宾斯。

;

;

; Tue, 10 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Scientists Study Long-lasting Ancient Structureshttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/scientists-study-long-lasting-ancient-structures/7296934.html
;;2023 年 10 月 9 日星期一 21:58:00 GMT;
;;
;;2023 年 8 月 24 日星期四，游客参观罗马万神殿圆顶的内部.（美联社照片/Andrew Medichini）;
;

;世界各地的古代建筑者创造的建筑在数千年后的今天仍然屹立不倒。

;

;罗马工程师建造了厚厚的;混凝土;海障。玛雅建筑商为他们的神创造了雕塑，中国建筑商则竖起围墙抵御入侵者。

;

;但是，许多最近的建筑已经开始倒塌。构成现代世界大部分的混凝土可以使用大约 50 到 100 年。

;

;越来越多的科学家一直在研究很久以前的材料。他们正在拆解建筑物的碎片并阅读历史文献，希望了解它们数千年来的情况。

;

;这项研究发现了一份令人惊讶的混入旧建筑的材料清单。它们包括树皮、火山灰、大米、啤酒甚至尿液。这些意想不到的材料可能会随着时间的推移而变得更加坚固，并在形成裂缝时“治愈”裂缝。

;

;弄清楚如何复制这些特征可能会对今天产生真正的影响。虽然我们的现代混凝土具有支撑非常高的建筑物和重型基础设施;的强度，但它无法与这些古老材料的;耐久性;竞争。

;

;随着气候变化威胁的日益加剧，人们越来越多地呼吁让建筑变得更加;可持续;。联合国最近的一份报告估计，建筑环境造成的二氧化碳排放量占全球二氧化碳排放量的三分之一以上。仅水泥生产就占了排放量的 7% 以上。

;

;;古罗马混凝土更好吗？;

;

;许多研究人员转向罗马人。从公元前 200 年左右开始，罗马帝国开始建造经得起时间考验的混凝土结构。其中包括万神殿到至今仍在输水的;渡槽;。

;

;即使在海水长期冲击建筑物的地方，您也会发现混凝土“基本上与以前一样”它是 2000 年前浇筑的，”约翰·奥尔森 (John Oleson) 说道。他是加拿大维多利亚大学的考古学家。

;

;大多数现代混凝土都是从波特兰水泥开始的，这是一种通过将石灰石和粘土加热至超高温并研磨而制成的粉末。将水泥与水混合形成;浆料;。然后，添加岩石和砾石等材质。

;
;;;游客走过科潘卫城，洪都拉斯西部的古玛雅遗址，2023 年 9 月 24 日星期日。（美联社照片/Moises Castillo）;
;

;古代建造者的记录显示罗马的过程类似。古代建造者将烧焦的石灰石和火山沙等材料与水和砾石混合，产生化学反应将所有东西连接在一起。

;

;现在，科学家认为他们已经找到了一些罗马混凝土能够支撑建筑物的重要原因。几千年来。这种古老的材料具有不寻常的自我修复能力。具体原因尚不清楚，但科学家们已开始寻找原因。

;

;Admir Masic 是麻省理工学院的土木和环境工程师。在一项研究中，他说这种力量来自于罗马材料中混合不均匀的;大块;石灰石。研究人员过去认为这些大块表明罗马人没有充分混合他们的材料。

;

;相反，科学家发现这些大块可以增强材料的“自我修复”能力。马西奇解释说，当裂缝形成时，水就会进入混凝土。水激活剩余的石灰，产生新的化学反应，可以填充受损的部分。

;

;;古罗马......摩天大楼？;

;

;今天的建筑商不能只是复制古老的流程。尽管罗马混凝土可以持续很长时间，但它无法支撑重型建筑物。 “你无法用罗马混凝土建造一座现代摩天大楼，”奥尔森说。 “当你到达第三层时，它就会崩溃。”

;

;相反，研究人员正在尝试将一些古代材料添加到现代混合物中。 Masic 所在的一家公司正在尝试使用“自愈”混凝土建造新项目。

;

;Masic 说，人们不需要像罗马人那样让事物持续很长时间才能产生影响。 。他说，如果我们将混凝土的使用寿命延长 50 或 100 年，“从长远来看，我们将需要更少的;拆除;、更少的维护和更少的材料。”

;

;我是 Dan诺瓦克。

;

;

;

; Tue, 10 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 WHO Approves a Second Malaria Vaccinehttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/who-approves-a-second-malaria-vaccine/7295083.html
;;2023 年 10 月 9 日星期一 22:05:58 GMT;
;;
;;文件 - 卢蒙巴县医院的护士为婴儿注射疟疾疫苗2022 年 7 月 1 日，肯尼亚基苏木。 (REUTERS/Baz Ratner);
;

;世界卫生组织 (WHO) 上周批准了第二种疟疾疫苗。这一决定可以提供一种成本更低、更容易获得的疫苗来帮助对抗这种疾病。

;

;世卫组织总干事谭德塞表示，联合国卫生机构根据两个专家组的建议批准了新的疟疾疫苗。他们建议可以给有患病风险的儿童注射疫苗。

;

;“作为一名疟疾研究人员，我曾经梦想有一天我们能够研制出一种安全有效的疟疾疫苗。现在我们有两种，”谭德塞说。

;

;英国牛津大学与印度血清研究所合作开发了新的三针疫苗。研究表明其有效率超过 75%。该疫苗可以通过额外注射（称为加强针）为人们提供一年的保护。谭德塞表示，这种疫苗的价格约为 2 至 4 美元，明年可能会在一些国家上市。

;

;今年早些时候，非洲国家加纳和布基纳法索的卫生官员也批准了该疫苗。

;

; >;

;;;文件 - 2019 年 12 月 11 日，马拉维的一名婴儿注射了世界上第一种疟疾疫苗。世界卫生组织批准了第二种疟疾疫苗，这种疫苗可以提供更便宜、更有效的疫苗注射抗寄生虫病。 （美联社照片/Jerome Delay，档案）;
;

;受感染的蚊子在叮咬人类时会传播;寄生虫;疾病。

;

;“这是又一个我们现在将拥有工具，但它不会取代蚊帐和;喷洒; ;杀虫剂;，”援助组织无国界医生组织的约翰·约翰逊说。 “这不是能够阻止疟疾的疫苗，”他补充道。约翰逊并未加入向世界卫生组织提供建议的专家组。

;

;世界卫生组织于 2021 年批准了第一种疟疾疫苗。该联合国机构将疫苗的开发描述为终结非洲致命疾病的“历史性”努力。全球估计有 2 亿疟疾病例和 40 万疟疾死亡病例，其中大部分都发生在非洲大陆。

;

;但是这种由葛兰素史克 (GSK) 生产的名为 Mosquirix 的疫苗的有效性只有 30% 左右。这种治疗需要注射四针，几个月内效果就会减弱。

;

;然而，世界卫生组织专家表示，迄今为止，葛兰素史克和牛津大学开发的疫苗的数据并不能表明哪一种更有效。

;

;美国政府将哥伦布日定为全国性假日1934 年，为了纪念探险家克里斯托弗·哥伦布。这一天是为了纪念哥伦布于 1492 年 10 月抵达美洲。

;最近，批评者表示，哥伦布并没有“发现”美洲，因为当地居民已经居住在那里。他的探索为欧洲人大规模迁徙到他们所谓的新大陆开辟了道路。这给许多原住民带来了战争、疾病和死亡。

;此后，一些美国州不再纪念哥伦布，而是庆祝美洲原住民日。

;;这幅艺术插图描绘了美国宇航局的 Psyche 航天器，它将对小行星进行直接探索成为一个剥离的行星核心。 (NASA/JPL-Caltech);

;美国宇航局 NASA 正准备发射一艘航天器，旨在观测一颗主要由金属制成的;小行星;。

;

;这艘名为 Psyche 的飞行器定于 10 月 12 日从佛罗里达州肯尼迪航天中心发射。

;

;该航天器将飞往一颗也称为 Psyche 的小行星。它在火星和木星之间绕太阳运行。 NASA;表示;这颗小行星是由一位意大利天文学家于 1852 年发现的。因为它是第 16 颗小行星被发现后，它有时也被称为 16 Psyche。

;

;Psyche 将是 NASA 首次前往含有大量金属的小行星的旅行或任务。过去的任务探索了主要由岩石或冰构成的小行星。

;

;天文学家表示，小行星 Psyche 的最宽处约为 280 公里。他们相信它可能是星子中心或核心的一部分。这是一个被认为是早期岩石行星的金属遗迹的物体。科学家认为普赛克主要由铁和镍组成，类似于地球的中心。

;

;美国宇航局认为，这颗小行星可能在太阳系早期形成期间发生的剧烈碰撞中分离。科学家认为，在这颗小行星上收集的数据可以提供有关包括地球在内的岩石行星如何形成的新细节。

;

;但美国宇航局表示，该物体也可能是其他东西，例如“一种不同类型的铁” -由太阳系某处富含金属的物质形成的丰富天体。”

;

;航天局 ;表示; Psyche 将在其储罐中携带近 1,000 公斤的推进剂氙气。氙气还用于汽车头灯和一些电视。该机构工程师估计，如果 Psyche 航天器使用传统化学推进器，该任务将需要燃烧大约 15 倍的推进剂。

;;;富兰克林·德拉诺·罗斯福;
;

;今天我们谈论的是富兰克林·德拉诺·罗斯福。早些时候我们讲述了他的权力崛起和他的健康问题。 39 岁时，罗斯福（人们常常这样称呼他）腰部以下;瘫痪;。他再也无法独立行走。

;

;但这并没有阻止他成为该国最有权势的总统之一。

;

;

;

;;总统任期：大萧条与新政;

;

;罗斯福上台时，美国正处于严重的经济萧条之中。许多农民无法出售农作物以获取利润。全国各地的银行都倒闭了。许多美国人失去了积蓄和家园。超过 25% 的劳动力没有工作。

;

;然而，当罗斯福 1933 年上任时，他告诉人们，“我们唯一要害怕的就是恐惧本身。”

;

;当美国人想到罗斯福时，他们经常会想到这句话。这显示了他的希望和;自信;精神，他因此而闻名。

;

;美国人还记得罗斯福开始担任总统的方式。在他的;前 100 天;中，他签署了 70 多项法案成为法律。其中一些导致了国家的重大变化。他们帮助稳定了国家的银行业，直接向农民和失业者提供联邦援助，并制定了公共工程计划。

;

;这些法案构成了罗斯福和其他人所谓的新政的基础。

;

;一些新政计划 - 包括;平民保护队;和;田纳西河谷管理局; – 创造了政府资助的就业机会。除了为工人提供薪水外，这些计划还旨在改善和保护该国的自然资源。例如，工人们植树、修路、修建水坝和发电厂。

;

;美国人今天仍在体验这些计划的影响。

;
;;;这张照片拍摄于 1933 年 3 月 12 日美国总统富兰克林·罗斯福开始向美国人民进行历史性的炉边谈话之前。（美联社照片）;
;

;罗斯福还因其与公众沟通的方式而被人们铭记。当时，多达 90% 的美国人拥有收音机。因此，罗斯福时不时地通过广播向公众发表讲话，这些广播被称为“;炉边谈话;”。

;

;这个词塑造了一种总统;舒适地;坐在壁炉旁，与几位亲密朋友进行非正式交谈的形象。事实上，罗斯福是在白宫的办公室发表这些讲话的。但他的声音很温暖，他以一种轻松、对话的方式向听众讲话，他称听众为“我的朋友”。

;

;罗斯福的希望、活力和对普通美国人的深情关怀相结合，使他很受欢迎与许多选民。 1936 年，他轻松连任。

;

;但罗斯福也有批评者。一些人指出他的许多计划都失败了。这些措施花费了很多钱，或者根本没有效果。

;

;其他人则表示，罗斯福大规模政府干预的政策不是美国式的。它限制了资本主义和自由市场。

;

;还有一些人指出，罗斯福的计划并没有平等地帮助每个人。许多新政计划旨在让年轻的美国白人参加工作。女性、少数族裔和年长的美国人经常被忽视。

;

;批评者和支持者都指出，罗斯福极大地扩大了总统权力。他为政府;行政部门;增加了一些全职职位。他还承担了国会制定法律的权力。

;

;甚至最高法院也发现罗斯福在某些情况下做得太过分了。它裁定他的一些行为非法。

;

;罗斯福担心最高法院也会阻止他的许多其他新政计划。于是他提出了一个规则。这将赋予总统任命六名新成员加入由九名成员组成的法院的权力。他的任命几乎肯定会确保他的新政计划能够继续下去。

;

;许多历史学家指出，罗斯福在“法庭挤塞”方面的努力是他试图扩大总统权力的最极端的例子之一。< /p>;

;但国会没有接受罗斯福的提议。最高法院仍有九名法官。

;

;但是，这些法官无论如何都继续批准罗斯福的行动。 They supported programs such as ;Social Security;, which was set up to help older adults, disabled people, and others who needed support; and the ;Wagner Act;, which permitted workers to organize in a trade union.

;

;While these efforts and other programs were important parts of FDR's reform efforts, they did not stop the Great Depression. None of the New Deal programs really did. The economy continued to struggle.

;

;;Presidency: Declaration of war;

;

;For several years, the president had been warning lawmakers and other Americans about the political forces in Japan, Germany, and Italy. Leaders in those countries supported nationalist movements and had already invaded or taken control of other areas.

;

;By 1941, more than 30 countries were involved in the conflict.

;

;Many Americans had wanted the US to remain neutral. They regretted becoming involved in World War I. For years, they had taken steps to prevent another major international conflict. Lawmakers had even banned the US government from selling or giving weapons to warring countries.

;

;But FDR believed World War II was different. He believed that Germany was the clear aggressor and needed to be stopped.

;

;So, in the 1930s, FDR received permission from Congress to provide weapons to the countries opposing Germany. After Germany took control of France, FDR received permission to give direct military aid to Britain.

;

;In addition, FDR began preparing the US military for war.

;

;On December 7, 1941, Japanese forces bombed American ships at the US Navy base in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. More than 2,400 Americans died at Pearl Harbor, and more than 1,700 were wounded.

;
;;;Declaring Japan guilty of an unprovoked attack, FDR asked Congress to declare war, Dec. 8, 1941. (AP Photo);
;

;The day after Pearl Harbor was attacked, Congress quickly approved FDR's request to declare war against Japan.

;

;Three days later, Germany and Italy declared war on the United States. American lawmakers responded ;in kind;. The US, which had remained neutral for many years, was now completely involved in World War II.

;

;;Presidency: World War II;

;

;During the war, FDR directed much of his attention to what would happen after the fighting stopped. He wanted to create an international order that would improve peace and cooperation. To that end, he helped organize 26 countries into a group he called the United Nations.

;

;FDR also believed that the world's future security depended, in large part, on cooperation between the US and the Soviet Union. He worked hard to create friendly relations with the Soviet leader, Joseph Stalin.

;
;;;A sand sculpture of (L to R) Churchill, Roosevelt and Stalin sitting together during the Yalta Conference in 1945.;
;

;Stalin, FDR, and British prime minister Winston Churchill all famously met at the Russian town of Yalta.

;

;There, the three men discussed plans to bring World War II to an end. They decided to demand that Germany surrender unconditionally. They also talked about diplomatic relations after the war ended.

;

;At the time, many Americans believed the ;Yalta conference; was a success. Soviet officials agreed to enter the war against Japan. In return, US officials said the Soviet government could re-gain control over parts of Northeastern China. Soviet officials also agreed to let countries in Eastern Europe hold free elections, and to share rights to veto UN decisions.

;

;In the eyes of many Americans, the Yalta agreement showed that the United States and the Soviet Union would be able to cooperate.

;

;;Legacy;

;

;FDR did not live to see the effects of the Yalta agreement, or even the end of the conflict.

;

;He had been president for 12 years. A few weeks before the Yalta Conference, he had been sworn-in yet again.

;

;FDR had already served longer than any US president. All others before him had followed the custom set by the first president, George Washington. They had served no more than two terms.

;

;In the winter of 1944, FDR was beginning his fourth term. But people close to him said he did not look well. Doctors also warned Roosevelt that his health was suffering.

;
;;;Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt in Warm Springs, Georgia Oct. 4, 1929. (AP Photo);
;

;So, in April, FDR went to a warm water; resort; in Georgia where he often rested and recovered his strength. There, he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage. In other words, his brain began to bleed.

;

;World leaders, including Stalin and Churchill, said they were shocked he had died. Many Americans felt the same. They stood alongside train tracks as his body was carried from Georgia to his childhood home in New York.

;

;He is buried there, at Hyde Park. In 1962, his wife Eleanor died and was buried next to him.

;

;Today, Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt are important ;figures; in US history. Many programs from the New Deal are still in effect now. FDR also changed the position of president into an active, powerful leader who legally intervenes in the economy and seems to have a personal relationship with Americans.

;

;And Eleanor Roosevelt developed a strong voice of her own. Her humanitarian efforts and work on behalf of civil rights and women's rights have given her a ;legacy; independent from her husband.

;

;Both admirers and critics point to the Roosevelts' influence as evidence of their strong feelings about the couple.

;

;I'm Kelly Jean Kelly.

;

;

;

;;Kelly Jean Kelly wrote this story for Learning English. George Grow was the editor.;

; Sun, 08 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 How Do You Stay “In Shape“?https://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/how-do-you-stay-in-shape-/7295362.html
;;Sat, 07 Oct 2023 21:59:00 GMT;
;;
;;FILE - People exercise inside Warren Hills cemetery in Harare, Zimbabwe, November 24 ,2022. (REUTERS/Philimon Bulawayo);
;

;And now, ;Words and Their Stories, ;from VOA Learning English.

;

;On this program, we explore words and expressions in the English language. We give you definitions, examples, and notes on usage.

;

;Today, we talk about ;fitness; and exercise. ;Keeping in shape; is a common expression for staying physically fit!

;

;What sort of exercise do you enjoy? How do you get in shape? If you are already in shape, how do you stay in shape?

;

;I used to walk a lot for work and that kept me in good shape. Five days a week I would walk to the train station, walk to the office and then climb stairs. At lunch, my coworkers and I would take a walk outside. Our office is in a beautiful area of Washington, DC, surrounded by ;museums; and ;monuments;. So that adds up to a lot of walking!

;

;But then, in 2020 like so many others, I started working from home. I became worried that without all that walking, I would quickly get out of shape! So, I made time for more swimming and short walks around my ;neighborhood;. Those two kept me in shape.

;

;Using the word “shape” when talking about fitness and health makes sense. Sometimes, we can describe the human body in terms of size and shape. But we can also use the word “shape” to talk about our projects, our activities, our actions and behaviors.

;

;So, ;shape up; also means to correct bad behavior. For example, a boss might warn an underperforming employee to ;shape up;. The boss may take this expression one step further. She or he might add a threat by saying ;shape up or ship out.;

;

;Talking about ships, we also describe things that are clean or running smoothly as ;shipshape;. A ship that is orderly and clean runs more smoothly and is safer. Remember, on a ship, you can be very far away from help. So, keeping things in good order prevents accidents and big problems.

;

;So, what happens if a situation or a project was in trouble but is now going well? Well, we can say ;things are shaping up;. If it's not going well, we can say the project is in ;bad shape;.

;

;Now, let's hear two friends use some of these expressions.

;

;;A: Hey, how's the project going?;

;

;;B: It's going well. Everything is ;shipshape; now.;

;

;;A: What do you mean 'now'?;

;

;;B: Well, last week we ran into some trouble. An employee ;wasn't pulling his weight; and things weren't getting done. ;

;

;;A: What did you do?;

;

;;B: I told him, “;Shape up or ship out;.” ;

;

;;A: That's pretty ;harsh;! ;

;

;;B: Maybe, but he ;shaped up;. Now he's a valuable member of the team. I think he was overworked and dealing with some personal issues.;

;

;;A: We all run into trouble sometimes. Hey, talking about being overworked … let's take a break in a bit. I need a walk!;

;

;;B: Sounds good. The project is in good shape. But I have to make sure I stay in good shape too!;

;

;And that's the end of this ;Words and Their Stories;. We hope you enjoyed learning some “shape” expressions and verbal phrases.

;

;Practice using them the next time you want to talk about getting or staying physically fit.

;

;Until next time … I'm Anna Matteo.

;

;

;

; Sun, 08 Oct 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Universities Work to Protect American Wine Grapes from Wildfire Smokehttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/universities-work-to-protect-american-wine-grapes-from-wildfire-smoke/7294285.html
;;Sat, 07 Oct 2023 22:05:51 GMT;
;;
;;Oregon State University students show Pinot noir grapes at the university's vineyard near Alpine, Ore., on Friday, Sept. 8, 2023. (AP Photo/Andrew Selsky);
;

;The West Coast of the United States produces over 90 percent of America's wine, an alcoholic drink. However, the area is also ;prone; to wildfires.

;

;Such fires cost the American wine industry billions of dollars in 2020. The smoke affects the; flavor; of the growing grapes that later become the wine. And, the flavor is undesirable, say some wine drinkers.

;

;So, wine experts from state universities in the area are working together to protect wine grapes from wildfire smoke.

;
;;;FILE - Smoke billows from a fire burning in the mountains over Napa Valley, Friday, Oct. 13, 2017, in Oakville, Calif. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File);
;

;In 2020, economists say, wildfires caused billions of dollars of losses, which included the wine industry.

;

;As a result, the US Department of Agriculture is paying for grape research at some state schools. They include University of California, Davis (UC Davis), Oregon State University and Washington State University. The research investment is worthy, agriculture officials say, because wine grapes are America's highest-value crop.

;
;;;Oregon State University researcher Cole Cerrato, left, and graduate student Lindsay Garcia prepare to send smoke from a small grill onto a row of wine grapes at the university's vineyard near Alpine, Ore., on Friday, Sept. 8, 2023. (AP Photo/Andrew Selsky);
;

;Tom Collins is a wine scientist at Washington State. He said “the ability to continue to make wine” is at risk in areas where smoke might be more common.

;

;Cole Cerrato is a researcher working on the problem in Oregon. He stood in Oregon State's vineyard, near the small town of Alpine. He lit a fire and blew the smoke through a hose and into a row of grapes covered in plastic.

;

;Cerrato and other researchers have done this before. They turned the treated grapes into wine. The result was, the wine had an unpleasant flavor of smoke and ash.

;
;;;A fire is lit inside a small grill that will send smoke into a structure enclosing wine grapes at the University of Oregon's vineyard near Alpine, Ore., on Friday, Sept. 8, 2023. (AP Photo/Andrew Selsky);
;

;The scientists are working to find a way to keep the smoke from getting through the grape skins and creating a bad taste in the wine.

;

;Some are trying to create a process that will treat wine and remove the smokiness. But they are concerned such a process might remove some of the wine's good flavors, too.

;

;Others think they can combine smoke-affected grapes with other grapes. The mix might lessen the smoky flavor.

;

;And Collins is working on a ;spray; made from water and a kind of clay that would protect the grapes from smoke. But all the grapes would need to be washed first before being turned into wine.

;

;Oregon State is experimenting with a similar spray treatment for grapes.

;

;In addition, the USDA has provided $7 million toward setting up smoke sensors in vineyards.

;

;Anita Oberholster is leading the efforts to save the wine grapes at UC Davis. In an internet post by UC Davis, she said a network of ;sensors; would help grape growers learn if their grapes are at risk. In addition, the readings from the sensors will permit the growers to prove their grapes are free from smoke damage.

;
;;;Oregon State University students show Pinot noir grapes at the university's vineyard near Alpine, Ore., on Friday, Sept. 8, 2023. (AP Photo/Andrew Selsky);
;

;Winemakers are glad that the universities are working to help the industry. Greg Jones runs the Abacela winery in southern Oregon and is the director of the state's winemaking trade group.

;

;He said the research has “gone a long way.” Now the grape-growers can quickly find out if the fruit has been hurt by the smoke. In the past, winemakers would not know about the wine until it was ready to drink.

;

;“I think it's increasingly clear that we're not likely to find a magic ;bullet;,” Collins said. But, he said, the researchers will find ways to keep the wine business successful.

;

;I'm Dan Friedell.

;

;

;

;;Dan Friedell adapted this story for Learning English based on a report by the Associated Press.;
